an4.19:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four ways of making prejudiced decisions.

an4.19:1.3.pli: Chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati—
an4.19:1.3.eng: Making decisions prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, and cowardice.

an4.19:1.4.eng: These are the four ways of making prejudiced decisions.

an4.19:2.1.eng: There are these four ways of making unprejudiced decisions.

an4.19:2.3.pli: Na chandāgatiṃ gacchati, na dosāgatiṃ gacchati, na mohāgatiṃ gacchati, na bhayāgatiṃ gacchati—
an4.19:2.3.eng: Making decisions unprejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, and cowardice.

an4.19:2.4.eng: These are the four ways of making unprejudiced decisions.

an4.19:3.1.eng: If you act against the teaching

an4.19:3.2.eng: out of favoritism, hostility, cowardice, or stupidity,

an4.19:3.4.eng: like the moon in the waning fortnight.

an4.19:4.1.eng: If you don’t act against the teaching

an4.19:4.2.eng: out of favoritism, hostility, cowardice, and stupidity,

an4.19:4.4.eng: like the moon in the waxing fortnight.”

an4.190:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
an4.190:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.

an4.190:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā tadahuposathe bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto nisinno hoti.
an4.190:1.2.eng: Now, at that time it was the sabbath, and the Buddha was sitting surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.

an4.190:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tuṇhībhūtaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ anuviloketvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
an4.190:1.3.eng: Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of mendicants, who were so very silent. He addressed them:

an4.190:2.1.pli: “Apalāpāyaṃ, bhikkhave, parisā nippalāpāyaṃ, bhikkhave, parisā suddhā sāre patiṭṭhitā.
an4.190:2.1.eng: “This assembly has no chaff, mendicants, it is free of chaff, pure, and consolidated in the core.

an4.190:2.2.pli: Tathārūpo ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhusaṅgho, tathārūpāyaṃ, bhikkhave, parisā.
an4.190:2.2.eng: Such is this Saṅgha of mendicants, such is this assembly!

an4.190:2.3.pli: Yathārūpā parisā dullabhā dassanāyapi lokasmiṃ, tathārūpo ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhusaṅgho, tathārūpāyaṃ, bhikkhave, parisā.
an4.190:2.3.eng: An assembly such as this is rarely seen in the world.

an4.190:2.4.pli: Yathārūpā parisā āhuneyyā pāhuneyyā dakkhiṇeyyā añjalikaraṇīyā anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa, tathārūpo ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhusaṅgho, tathārūpāyaṃ, bhikkhave, parisā.
an4.190:2.4.eng: An assembly such as this is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an4.190:2.5.pli: Yathārūpāya parisāya appaṃ dinnaṃ bahu hoti bahu dinnaṃ bahutaraṃ, tathārūpo ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhusaṅgho, tathārūpāyaṃ, bhikkhave, parisā.
an4.190:2.5.eng: For an assembly such as this, giving little becomes much, while giving much becomes even more.

an4.190:2.6.pli: Yathārūpaṃ parisaṃ alaṃ yojanagaṇanānipi dassanāya gantuṃ api puṭosenāpi, tathārūpo ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhusaṅgho, tathārūpāyaṃ, bhikkhave, parisā.
an4.190:2.6.eng: An assembly such as this is worth traveling many leagues to see, even if you have to carry your own provisions in a knapsack.

an4.190:3.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, bhikkhū imasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe devappattā viharanti;
an4.190:3.1.eng: There are mendicants staying in this Saṅgha who have attained to the gods.

an4.190:3.2.pli: santi, bhikkhave, bhikkhū imasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe brahmappattā viharanti;
an4.190:3.2.eng: There are mendicants staying in this Saṅgha who have attained to divinity.

an4.190:3.3.pli: santi, bhikkhave, bhikkhū imasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe āneñjappattā viharanti;
an4.190:3.3.eng: There are mendicants staying in this Saṅgha who have attained to the imperturbable.

an4.190:3.4.pli: santi, bhikkhave, bhikkhū imasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe ariyappattā viharanti.
an4.190:3.4.eng: There are mendicants staying in this Saṅgha who have attained to nobility.

an4.190:4.1.eng: And how has a mendicant attained to the gods?

an4.190:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
an4.190:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption …

an4.190:4.3.pli: vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.190:4.3.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption …

an4.190:4.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu devappatto hoti.
an4.190:4.4.eng: That’s how a mendicant has attained to the gods.

an4.190:5.1.eng: And how has a mendicant attained to divinity?

an4.190:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ tathā tatiyaṃ tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
an4.190:5.2.eng: Firstly, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

an4.190:5.3.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of compassion …

an4.190:5.5.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ tathā tatiyaṃ tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
an4.190:5.5.eng: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

an4.190:5.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu brahmappatto hoti.
an4.190:5.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant has attained to divinity.

an4.190:6.1.eng: And how has a mendicant attained to the imperturbable?

an4.190:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.190:6.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant—going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity—aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

an4.190:6.3.pli: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.190:6.3.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, he enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

an4.190:6.4.pli: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.190:6.4.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, he enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.

an4.190:6.5.pli: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.190:6.5.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, he enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

an4.190:6.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āneñjappatto hoti.
an4.190:6.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant has attained to the imperturbable.

an4.190:7.1.eng: And how has a mendicant attained to nobility?

an4.190:7.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an4.190:7.2.eng: It’s when they truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an4.190:7.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyappatto hotī”ti.
an4.190:7.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has attained to nobility.”

an4.191:1.1.pli: “Sotānugatānaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ, vacasā paricitānaṃ, manasānupekkhitānaṃ, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhānaṃ cattāro ānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā.
an4.191:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you can expect four benefits when the teachings have been followed by ear, consolidated by voice, examined by the mind, and well comprehended theoretically.

an4.191:1.3.eng: Take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching—

an4.191:1.4.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.
an4.191:1.4.eng: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.

an4.191:1.5.pli: Tassa te dhammā sotānugatā honti, vacasā paricitā, manasānupekkhitā, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
an4.191:1.5.eng: They’ve followed those teachings by ear, consolidated them by voice, examined them by the mind, and well comprehended them theoretically.

an4.191:1.6.pli: So muṭṭhassati kālaṃ kurumāno aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ upapajjati.
an4.191:1.6.eng: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.

an4.191:1.7.eng: Being happy there, passages of the teaching come back to them.

an4.191:1.9.pli: atha so satto khippaṃyeva visesagāmī hoti.
an4.191:1.9.eng: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.

an4.191:1.10.pli: Sotānugatānaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ, vacasā paricitānaṃ, manasānupekkhitānaṃ, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhānaṃ ayaṃ paṭhamo ānisaṃso pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.191:1.10.eng: This is the first benefit you can expect when the teachings have been followed by ear, consolidated by voice, examined by the mind, and well comprehended theoretically.

an4.191:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇāti—
an4.191:2.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching—

an4.191:2.2.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.
an4.191:2.2.eng: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.

an4.191:2.3.pli: Tassa te dhammā sotānugatā honti, vacasā paricitā, manasānupekkhitā, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
an4.191:2.3.eng: They’ve followed those teachings by ear, consolidated them by voice, examined them by the mind, and well comprehended them theoretically.

an4.191:2.4.pli: So muṭṭhassati kālaṃ kurumāno aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ upapajjati.
an4.191:2.4.eng: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.

an4.191:2.5.pli: Tassa tattha na heva kho sukhino dhammapadā plavanti;
an4.191:2.5.eng: Though they’re happy there, passages of the teaching don’t come back to them.

an4.191:2.6.pli: api ca kho bhikkhu iddhimā cetovasippatto devaparisāyaṃ dhammaṃ deseti.
an4.191:2.6.eng: However, a mendicant with psychic powers, who has achieved mastery of the mind, teaches Dhamma to the assembly of gods.

an4.191:2.8.pli: ‘ayaṃ vā so dhammavinayo, yatthāhaṃ pubbe brahmacariyaṃ acarin’ti.
an4.191:2.8.eng: ‘I used to lead the spiritual life in this same teaching and training.’

an4.191:2.10.pli: atha so satto khippameva visesagāmī hoti.
an4.191:2.10.eng: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.

an4.191:2.11.eng: Suppose a person was skilled in the sound of drums.

an4.191:2.12.eng: While traveling along a road they hear the sound of drums.

an4.191:2.13.pli: Tassa na heva kho assa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā:
an4.191:2.13.eng: They wouldn’t have any doubts or uncertainties about whether

an4.191:2.14.pli: ‘bherisaddo nu kho, na nu kho bherisaddo’ti.
an4.191:2.14.eng: that was the sound of drums or not.

an4.191:2.15.eng: They’d just conclude, ‘That’s the sound of drums.’

an4.191:2.16.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇāti—
an4.191:2.16.eng: In the same way, take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching …

an4.191:2.17.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.

an4.191:2.18.pli: Tassa te dhammā sotānugatā honti, vacasā paricitā, manasānupekkhitā, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.

an4.191:2.19.pli: So muṭṭhassati kālaṃ kurumāno aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ upapajjati.
an4.191:2.19.eng: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods. …

an4.191:2.20.pli: Tassa tattha na heva kho sukhino dhammapadā plavanti;

an4.191:2.21.pli: api ca kho bhikkhu iddhimā cetovasippatto devaparisāyaṃ dhammaṃ deseti.

an4.191:2.23.pli: ‘ayaṃ vā so dhammavinayo, yatthāhaṃ pubbe brahmacariyaṃ acarin’ti.

an4.191:2.25.pli: atha so satto khippaṃyeva visesagāmī hoti.
an4.191:2.25.eng: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.

an4.191:2.26.pli: Sotānugatānaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ, vacasā paricitānaṃ, manasānupekkhitānaṃ, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhānaṃ ayaṃ dutiyo ānisaṃso pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.191:2.26.eng: This is the second benefit you can expect when the teachings have been followed by ear, consolidated by voice, examined by the mind, and well comprehended theoretically.

an4.191:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇāti—
an4.191:3.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching—

an4.191:3.2.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.
an4.191:3.2.eng: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.

an4.191:3.3.pli: Tassa te dhammā sotānugatā honti, vacasā paricitā, manasānupekkhitā, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
an4.191:3.3.eng: They’ve followed those teachings by ear, consolidated them by voice, examined them by the mind, and well comprehended them theoretically.

an4.191:3.4.pli: So muṭṭhassati kālaṃ kurumāno aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ upapajjati.
an4.191:3.4.eng: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.

an4.191:3.5.pli: Tassa tattha na heva kho sukhino dhammapadā plavanti, napi bhikkhu iddhimā cetovasippatto devaparisāyaṃ dhammaṃ deseti;
an4.191:3.5.eng: But passages of the teaching don’t come back to them when they’re happy, nor does a mendicant with psychic powers … teach Dhamma to the assembly of gods.

an4.191:3.6.pli: api ca kho devaputto devaparisāyaṃ dhammaṃ deseti.
an4.191:3.6.eng: However, a godling teaches Dhamma to the assembly of gods.

an4.191:3.8.pli: ‘ayaṃ vā so dhammavinayo, yatthāhaṃ pubbe brahmacariyaṃ acarin’ti.
an4.191:3.8.eng: ‘I used to lead the spiritual life in this same teaching and training.’

an4.191:3.10.pli: atha so satto khippaṃyeva visesagāmī hoti.
an4.191:3.10.eng: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.

an4.191:3.11.eng: Suppose a person was skilled in the sound of horns.

an4.191:3.12.eng: While traveling along a road they hear the sound of horns.

an4.191:3.13.pli: Tassa na heva kho assa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā:
an4.191:3.13.eng: They wouldn’t have any doubt about whether

an4.191:3.14.pli: ‘saṅkhasaddo nu kho, na nu kho saṅkhasaddo’ti.
an4.191:3.14.eng: that was the sound of horns or not.

an4.191:3.15.eng: They’d just conclude, ‘That’s the sound of horns.’

an4.191:3.16.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇāti—
an4.191:3.16.eng: In the same way, take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching …

an4.191:3.17.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.

an4.191:3.18.pli: Tassa te dhammā sotānugatā honti, vacasā paricitā, manasānupekkhitā, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.

an4.191:3.19.pli: So muṭṭhassati kālaṃ kurumāno aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ upapajjati.
an4.191:3.19.eng: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods. …

an4.191:3.20.pli: Tassa tattha na heva kho sukhino dhammapadā plavanti, napi bhikkhu iddhimā cetovasippatto devaparisāyaṃ dhammaṃ deseti;

an4.191:3.21.pli: api ca kho devaputto devaparisāyaṃ dhammaṃ deseti.

an4.191:3.23.pli: ‘ayaṃ vā so dhammavinayo, yatthāhaṃ pubbe brahmacariyaṃ acarin’ti.

an4.191:3.25.pli: atha so satto khippaṃyeva visesagāmī hoti.
an4.191:3.25.eng: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.

an4.191:3.26.pli: Sotānugatānaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ, vacasā paricitānaṃ, manasānupekkhitānaṃ, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhānaṃ ayaṃ tatiyo ānisaṃso pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.191:3.26.eng: This is the third benefit you can expect when the teachings have been followed by ear, consolidated by voice, examined by the mind, and well comprehended theoretically.

an4.191:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇāti—
an4.191:4.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching—

an4.191:4.2.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.
an4.191:4.2.eng: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.

an4.191:4.3.pli: Tassa te dhammā sotānugatā honti, vacasā paricitā, manasānupekkhitā, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
an4.191:4.3.eng: They’ve followed those teachings by ear, consolidated them by voice, examined them by the mind, and well comprehended them theoretically.

an4.191:4.4.pli: So muṭṭhassati kālaṃ kurumāno aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ upapajjati.
an4.191:4.4.eng: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.

an4.191:4.5.pli: Tassa tattha na heva kho sukhino dhammapadā plavanti, napi bhikkhu iddhimā cetovasippatto devaparisāyaṃ dhammaṃ deseti, napi devaputto devaparisāyaṃ dhammaṃ deseti;
an4.191:4.5.eng: But passages of the teaching don’t come back to them when they’re happy, and neither a mendicant with psychic powers … nor a godling teaches Dhamma to the assembly of gods.

an4.191:4.6.pli: api ca kho opapātiko opapātikaṃ sāreti:
an4.191:4.6.eng: But a being who has been reborn spontaneously reminds another such being:

an4.191:4.7.pli: ‘sarasi tvaṃ, mārisa, sarasi tvaṃ, mārisa, yattha mayaṃ pubbe brahmacariyaṃ acarimhā’ti.
an4.191:4.7.eng: ‘Do you remember, good fellow? Do you remember where we used to lead the spiritual life?’

an4.191:4.11.pli: atha so satto khippaṃyeva visesagāmī hoti.
an4.191:4.11.eng: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.

an4.191:4.12.eng: Suppose there were two friends who had played together in the sand.

an4.191:4.13.eng: Some time or other they’d meet.

an4.191:4.14.pli: Añño pana sahāyako sahāyakaṃ evaṃ vadeyya:
an4.191:4.14.eng: And one friend would say to the other:

an4.191:4.15.eng: ‘Do you remember this, friend? Do you remember that, friend?’

an4.191:4.18.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇāti—
an4.191:4.18.eng: In the same way, take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching …

an4.191:4.19.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.

an4.191:4.20.pli: Tassa te dhammā sotānugatā honti, vacasā paricitā, manasānupekkhitā, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.

an4.191:4.21.pli: So muṭṭhassati kālaṃ kurumāno aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ upapajjati.
an4.191:4.21.eng: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods. …

an4.191:4.22.pli: Tassa tattha na heva kho sukhino dhammapadā plavanti, napi bhikkhu iddhimā cetovasippatto devaparisāyaṃ dhammaṃ deseti, napi devaputto devaparisāyaṃ dhammaṃ deseti;

an4.191:4.23.pli: api ca kho opapātiko opapātikaṃ sāreti:

an4.191:4.24.pli: ‘sarasi tvaṃ, mārisa, sarasi tvaṃ, mārisa, yattha mayaṃ pubbe brahmacariyaṃ acarimhā’ti.

an4.191:4.28.pli: atha kho so satto khippaṃyeva visesagāmī hoti.
an4.191:4.28.eng: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.

an4.191:4.29.pli: Sotānugatānaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ, vacasā paricitānaṃ, manasānupekkhitānaṃ, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhānaṃ ayaṃ catuttho ānisaṃso pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.191:4.29.eng: This is the fourth benefit you can expect when the teachings have been followed by ear, consolidated by voice, examined by the mind, and well comprehended theoretically.

an4.191:4.30.pli: Sotānugatānaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ, vacasā paricitānaṃ, manasānupekkhitānaṃ diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhānaṃ ime cattāro ānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā”ti.
an4.191:4.30.eng: You can expect these four benefits when the teachings have been followed by ear, consolidated by voice, examined by the mind, and well comprehended theoretically.”

an4.192:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four things can be known in four situations.

an4.192:1.3.pli: Saṃvāsena, bhikkhave, sīlaṃ veditabbaṃ, tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññena.
an4.192:1.3.eng: You can get to know a person’s ethics by living with them. But only after a long time, not casually; only when attentive, not when inattentive; and only by the wise, not the witless.

an4.192:1.4.pli: Saṃvohārena, bhikkhave, soceyyaṃ veditabbaṃ, tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññena.
an4.192:1.4.eng: You can get to know a person’s purity by dealing with them. …

an4.192:1.5.pli: Āpadāsu, bhikkhave, thāmo veditabbo, so ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññena.
an4.192:1.5.eng: You can get to know a person’s resilience in times of trouble. …

an4.192:1.6.pli: Sākacchāya, bhikkhave, paññā veditabbā, sā ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenāti.
an4.192:1.6.eng: You can get to know a person’s wisdom by discussion. But only after a long time, not casually; only when attentive, not when inattentive; and only by the wise, not the witless.

an4.192:2.1.pli: ‘Saṃvāsena, bhikkhave, sīlaṃ veditabbaṃ, tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā’ti,
an4.192:2.1.eng: ‘You can get to know a person’s ethics by living with them. But only after a long time, not casually; only when attentive, not when inattentive; and only by the wise, not the witless.’

an4.192:2.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an4.192:2.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an4.192:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalena saddhiṃ saṃvasamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an4.192:2.3.eng: Take an individual who’s living with someone else. They come to know:

an4.192:2.4.pli: ‘dīgharattaṃ kho ayamāyasmā khaṇḍakārī chiddakārī sabalakārī kammāsakārī, na santatakārī na santatavutti;
an4.192:2.4.eng: ‘For a long time this venerable’s deeds have been broken, tainted, spotty, and marred. Their deeds and behavior are inconsistent.

an4.192:2.5.eng: This venerable is unethical, not ethical.’

an4.192:3.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalena saddhiṃ saṃvasamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an4.192:3.1.eng: Take another individual who’s living with someone else. They come to know:

an4.192:3.2.pli: ‘dīgharattaṃ kho ayamāyasmā akhaṇḍakārī acchiddakārī asabalakārī akammāsakārī santatakārī santatavutti;
an4.192:3.2.eng: ‘For a long time this venerable’s deeds have been intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred. Their deeds and behavior are consistent.

an4.192:3.3.eng: This venerable is ethical, not unethical.’

an4.192:3.4.pli: ‘Saṃvāsena, bhikkhave, sīlaṃ veditabbaṃ, tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā’ti, iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an4.192:3.4.eng: That’s why I said that you can get to know a person’s ethics by living with them. But only after a long time, not a short time; only when attentive, not when inattentive; and only by the wise, not the witless.

an4.192:4.1.pli: ‘Saṃvohārena, bhikkhave, soceyyaṃ veditabbaṃ, tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā’ti,
an4.192:4.1.eng: ‘You can get to know a person’s purity by dealing with them. …’

an4.192:4.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an4.192:4.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an4.192:4.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalena saddhiṃ saṃvoharamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an4.192:4.3.eng: Take an individual who has dealings with someone else. They come to know:

an4.192:4.4.pli: ‘aññathā kho ayamāyasmā ekena eko voharati, aññathā dvīhi, aññathā tīhi, aññathā sambahulehi;
an4.192:4.4.eng: ‘This venerable deals with one person in one way. Then they deal with two, three, or many people each in different ways.

an4.192:4.5.eng: They’re not consistent from one deal to the next.

an4.192:4.6.eng: This venerable’s dealings are impure, not pure.’

an4.192:5.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalena saddhiṃ saṃvoharamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an4.192:5.1.eng: Take another individual who has dealings with someone else. They come to know:

an4.192:5.2.pli: ‘yatheva kho ayamāyasmā ekena eko voharati, tathā dvīhi, tathā tīhi, tathā sambahulehi.
an4.192:5.2.eng: ‘This venerable deals with one person in one way. Then they deal with two, three, or many people each in the same way.

an4.192:5.3.eng: They’re consistent from one deal to the next.

an4.192:5.4.eng: This venerable’s dealings are pure, not impure.’

an4.192:5.5.pli: ‘Saṃvohārena, bhikkhave, soceyyaṃ veditabbaṃ, tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā’ti, iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an4.192:5.5.eng: That’s why I said that you can get to know a person’s purity by dealing with them. …

an4.192:6.1.pli: ‘Āpadāsu, bhikkhave, thāmo veditabbo, so ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā’ti,
an4.192:6.1.eng: ‘You can get to know a person’s resilience in times of trouble. …’

an4.192:6.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an4.192:6.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an4.192:6.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco ñātibyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno, bhogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno, rogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno na iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an4.192:6.3.eng: Take someone who experiences loss of family, wealth, or health. But they don’t reflect:

an4.192:6.4.pli: ‘tathābhūto kho ayaṃ lokasannivāso tathābhūto ayaṃ attabhāvapaṭilābho yathābhūte lokasannivāse yathābhūte attabhāvapaṭilābhe aṭṭha lokadhammā lokaṃ anuparivattanti loko ca aṭṭha lokadhamme anuparivattati—
an4.192:6.4.eng: ‘Worldly life is like that. Incarnation is like that. That’s why the eight worldly conditions revolve around the world, and the world revolves around the eight worldly conditions:

an4.192:6.5.pli: lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṃsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañcā’ti.
an4.192:6.5.eng: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, pleasure and pain.’

an4.192:6.6.pli: So ñātibyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno bhogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno rogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an4.192:6.6.eng: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an4.192:7.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco ñātibyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno bhogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno rogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an4.192:7.1.eng: Take someone else who experiences loss of family, wealth, or health. But they reflect:

an4.192:7.2.pli: ‘tathābhūto kho ayaṃ lokasannivāso tathābhūto ayaṃ attabhāvapaṭilābho yathābhūte lokasannivāse yathābhūte attabhāvapaṭilābhe aṭṭha lokadhammā lokaṃ anuparivattanti loko ca aṭṭha lokadhamme anuparivattati—
an4.192:7.2.eng: ‘Worldly life is like that. Incarnation is like that. That’s why the eight worldly conditions revolve around the world, and the world revolves around the eight worldly conditions:

an4.192:7.3.pli: lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṃsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañcā’ti.
an4.192:7.3.eng: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, pleasure and pain.’

an4.192:7.4.pli: So ñātibyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno bhogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno rogabyasanena vā phuṭṭho samāno na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an4.192:7.4.eng: They don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an4.192:7.5.pli: ‘Āpadāsu, bhikkhave, thāmo veditabbo, so ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā’ti,
an4.192:7.5.eng: That’s why I said that you can get to know a person’s resilience in times of trouble. …

an4.192:7.6.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.

an4.192:8.1.pli: ‘Sākacchāya, bhikkhave, paññā veditabbā, sā ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā’ti,
an4.192:8.1.eng: ‘You can get to know a person’s wisdom by discussion. But only after a long time, not casually; only when attentive, not when inattentive; and only by the wise, not the witless.’

an4.192:8.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an4.192:8.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an4.192:8.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalena saddhiṃ sākacchāyamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an4.192:8.3.eng: Take an individual who is discussing with someone else. They come to know:

an4.192:8.4.pli: ‘yathā kho imassa āyasmato ummaggo yathā ca abhinīhāro yathā ca pañhāsamudāhāro, duppañño ayamāyasmā, nāyamāyasmā paññavā.
an4.192:8.4.eng: ‘Judging by this venerable’s approach, by what they’re getting at, and by how they discuss a question, they’re witless, not wise.

an4.192:8.6.pli: Tathā hi ayamāyasmā na ceva gambhīraṃ atthapadaṃ udāharati santaṃ paṇītaṃ atakkāvacaraṃ nipuṇaṃ paṇḍitavedanīyaṃ.
an4.192:8.6.eng: This venerable does not bring up a deep and meaningful saying that is peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.

an4.192:8.7.pli: Yañca ayamāyasmā dhammaṃ bhāsati tassa ca nappaṭibalo saṅkhittena vā vitthārena vā atthaṃ ācikkhituṃ desetuṃ paññāpetuṃ paṭṭhapetuṃ vivarituṃ vibhajituṃ uttānīkātuṃ.
an4.192:8.7.eng: When this venerable speaks on Dhamma they’re not able to explain the meaning, either briefly or in detail. They can’t teach it, assert it, establish it, clarify it, analyze it, or reveal it.

an4.192:8.8.eng: This venerable is witless, not wise.’

an4.192:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, cakkhumā puriso udakarahadassa tīre ṭhito passeyya parittaṃ macchaṃ ummujjamānaṃ.
an4.192:9.1.eng: Suppose a person with clear eyes was standing on the bank of a lake. They’d see a little fish rising,

an4.192:9.3.pli: ‘yathā kho imassa macchassa ummaggo yathā ca ūmighāto yathā ca vegāyitattaṃ, paritto ayaṃ maccho, nāyaṃ maccho mahanto’ti.
an4.192:9.3.eng: ‘Judging by this fish’s approach, by the ripples it makes, and by its force, it’s a little fish, not a big one.’

an4.192:9.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalena saddhiṃ sākacchāyamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an4.192:9.4.eng: In the same way, an individual who is discussing with someone else would come to know:

an4.192:9.5.pli: ‘yathā kho imassa āyasmato ummaggo yathā ca abhinīhāro yathā ca pañhāsamudāhāro, duppañño ayamāyasmā, nāyamāyasmā paññavā.
an4.192:9.5.eng: ‘Judging by this venerable’s approach, by what they’re getting at, and by how they discuss a question, they’re witless, not wise. …’

an4.192:9.7.pli: Tathā hi ayamāyasmā na ceva gambhīraṃ atthapadaṃ udāharati santaṃ paṇītaṃ atakkāvacaraṃ nipuṇaṃ paṇḍitavedanīyaṃ.

an4.192:9.8.pli: Yañca ayamāyasmā dhammaṃ bhāsati, tassa ca na paṭibalo saṅkhittena vā vitthārena vā atthaṃ ācikkhituṃ desetuṃ paññāpetuṃ paṭṭhapetuṃ vivarituṃ vibhajituṃ uttānīkātuṃ.

an4.192:10.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalena saddhiṃ sākacchāyamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an4.192:10.1.eng: Take another individual who is discussing with someone else. They come to know:

an4.192:10.2.pli: ‘yathā kho imassa āyasmato ummaggo yathā ca abhinīhāro yathā ca pañhāsamudāhāro, paññavā ayamāyasmā, nāyamāyasmā duppañño.
an4.192:10.2.eng: ‘Judging by this venerable’s approach, by what they’re getting at, and by how they discuss a question, they’re wise, not witless.

an4.192:10.4.pli: Tathā hi ayamāyasmā gambhīrañceva atthapadaṃ udāharati santaṃ paṇītaṃ atakkāvacaraṃ nipuṇaṃ paṇḍitavedanīyaṃ.
an4.192:10.4.eng: This venerable brings up a deep and meaningful saying that is peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.

an4.192:10.5.pli: Yañca ayamāyasmā dhammaṃ bhāsati, tassa ca paṭibalo saṅkhittena vā vitthārena vā atthaṃ ācikkhituṃ desetuṃ paññāpetuṃ paṭṭhapetuṃ vivarituṃ vibhajituṃ uttānīkātuṃ.
an4.192:10.5.eng: When this venerable speaks on Dhamma they’re able to explain the meaning, either briefly or in detail. They teach it, assert it, establish it, clarify it, analyze it, and reveal it.

an4.192:10.6.eng: This venerable is wise, not witless.’

an4.192:11.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, cakkhumā puriso udakarahadassa tīre ṭhito passeyya mahantaṃ macchaṃ ummujjamānaṃ.
an4.192:11.1.eng: Suppose a man with clear eyes was standing on the bank of a lake. He’d see a big fish rising,

an4.192:11.3.pli: ‘yathā kho imassa macchassa ummaggo yathā ca ūmighāto yathā ca vegāyitattaṃ, mahanto ayaṃ maccho, nāyaṃ maccho paritto’ti.
an4.192:11.3.eng: ‘Judging by this fish’s approach, by the ripples it makes, and by its force, it’s a big fish, not a little one.’

an4.192:11.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo puggalena saddhiṃ sākacchāyamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an4.192:11.4.eng: In the same way, an individual who is discussing with someone else would come to know:

an4.192:11.5.pli: ‘yathā kho imassa āyasmato ummaggo yathā ca abhinīhāro yathā ca pañhāsamudāhāro, paññavā ayamāyasmā, nāyamāyasmā duppañño.
an4.192:11.5.eng: ‘Judging by this venerable’s approach, by what they’re getting at, and by how they articulate a question, they’re wise, not witless. …’

an4.192:11.7.pli: Tathā hi ayamāyasmā gambhīrañceva atthapadaṃ udāharati santaṃ paṇītaṃ atakkāvacaraṃ nipuṇaṃ paṇḍitavedanīyaṃ.

an4.192:11.8.pli: Yañca ayamāyasmā dhammaṃ bhāsati, tassa ca paṭibalo saṅkhittena vā vitthārena vā atthaṃ ācikkhituṃ desetuṃ paññāpetuṃ paṭṭhapetuṃ vivarituṃ vibhajituṃ uttānīkātuṃ.

an4.192:12.1.pli: ‘Sākacchāya, bhikkhave, paññā veditabbā, sā ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā’ti, iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an4.192:12.1.eng: That’s why I said that you can get to know a person’s wisdom by discussion. But only after a long time, not casually; only when attentive, not when inattentive; and only by the wise, not the witless.

an4.192:12.2.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri ṭhānāni imehi catūhi ṭhānehi veditabbānī”ti.
an4.192:12.2.eng: These are the four things that can be known in four situations.”
